definitions.definition: to make something seem larger, better, worse or more important than it really is

examples.text: The hotel was really filthy and I'm not exaggerating.
He tends to exaggerate the difficulties.
I'm sure he exaggerates his Irish accent *(= tries to sound more Irish than he really is)*.
Demand for the product has been greatly exaggerated.
The media has exaggerated the extent of this problem.
The historical significance of these events can be easily exaggerated.

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent.: from Latin exaggerat- ‘heaped up’, from the verb exaggerare, from ex- ‘thoroughly’ + aggerare ‘heap up’ (from agger ‘heap’). The word originally meant ‘pile up, accumulate’, later ‘increase praise or blame’, giving rise to current senses.
